awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Conformal Stamp Printing for 3D Curvilinear Electronics Manufacturing
awd_abstract_narration:
Electronics constructed in 3D curvilinear layouts have many applications; examples include smart contact lens with sensors integrated, wide field-of-view cameras from curved image sensor arrays, and spherical helix antennas with high radiation efficiency. However, it is very challenging to create 3D curvilinear electronics due to manufacturing technology gaps. This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) award supports fundamental research to provide needed knowledge to develop conformal stamp printing approach for 3D curvilinear electronics manufacturing. 3D curvilinear electronics made from conformal stamp printing can be used in healthcare, space, telecommunication, and energy industries. Therefore, outcomes from this research will benefit the U.S. economy and society. The award will also support educational and outreach activities, such as providing learning opportunities to high school students and their teachers, offering research experiences for undergraduate students (especially those from the underrepresented groups), and disseminating the latest science and engineering knowledge to the general public.

Conformal stamp printing involves employing an inflated elastomeric balloon (conformal stamp) to pick-up and print electronic components (inks) onto curvilinear surfaces to create 3D curvilinear electronics. The first research objective is to establish the relationship between the deformation and induced strain in the stamp. To achieve this objective, the stamp's material properties, including strain-stress relationship and modulus, will be characterized by tension tests of thin elastomeric sheets. Employing the measured properties, both analytical models based on strain energy in the stamp and finite element simulations of inflated stamp under deformation will be used to predict the quantitative relationship between the deformation and associated strain. The second objective is to quantify the effects of stamp peeling speed on the interfacial adhesion strength between stamp and inks. To achieve this objective, a model of adhesion strength related to peeling speed will be built based on the energy release rate when peeling to crack an interface between rigid silicon (ink) and viscoelastic elastomer (stamp). After being verified by experiments, the model will be used to predict the effects of peeling speed on interfacial adhesion strength. The third objective is to establish the relationship between the deformation of the stamp and the deformation, strain and pattern distortion of the inks. To achieve this objective, finite element simulations of the inks at deformed states during and after printing will be performed. After being verified by experiments, the simulations will be utilized to capture the inks' deformation, strain and pattern distortion with various deformation conditions of the stamp.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
This project developed a novel manufacturing technology, namely ?conformal additive stamp printing?, and underpinned the fundamental working principle of the technology. Electronics constructed in 3D curvilinear layouts have many applications; examples include retina protheses, smart contact lens with sensors integrated, wide field-of-view cameras from curved image sensor arrays, and spherical helix antennas with high radiation efficiency, biomedical devices to conform with curved organ surfaces. However, it is very challenging to create these 3D curvilinear electronics due to manufacturing technology gaps. This project supported the invention of the conformal additive stamp printing technology and supported the understanding of the working principles and the development of the prototypes of several 3D curvy devices.  Conformal additive stamp printing uses an inflated elastomeric balloon (conformal stamp) to pick-up and print electronic components (inks) onto curvilinear surfaces to create 3D curvilinear electronics. The softness and deformability of the elastomeric balloon renders conformal stamp printing a key advantage that it can form intimate contact with complex 3D surfaces and thus can print inks on 3D substrates, which was not achievable before.

 

This research findings of the project are multi-folds; and a set of knowledge has been generated. Firstly, conformal additive stamp printing based on both manual operation and semi-automatic operation is proven to be robust and effective to manufacture curvy electronics. Secondly, the fundamental understanding is gained on how the conformal stamp printing process works and how the governing factor affects the picking-up and printing process via a conformal balloon stamp, and how the stamp and ink behave. Thirdly, the ink mainly undergoes minimized mechanical strain while the balloon stamp takes majority of the deformation during the manufacturing process. Fourthly, the pattern distortion associated with the conformal additive stamp process could be captured precisely and inverse design between the targeted ink patterns and original ink patterns could be achieved through analytical modeling. Fifthly, the curvy and shape adaptive imager can be achieved based on the conformal additive stamp printing technology and could outperform the biological counterpart. The findings from this research will open the major roadblock for 3D curvilinear electronics manufacturing and promise many unique curvy devices in emerging applications.

 

The outcomes of the project also lie in the integration of research into education and outreach activities and also the dissemination of knowledge to a broader audience. This project nurtured a dozen of underrepresented students, including 1 African American student, 3 female students. In particular, four undergraduate researchers, including two female students, after participating this project, pursued graduate degrees. The research findings on the conformal additive stamp printing and various curvy electronic devices were disseminated into senior elective and graduate level classes and also introduced to more than 150 high school students and their teachers via workshops sponsored by the PI. The research findings on the design, principle, and applications of conformal additive stamp printing and various curvy electronic devices, such as smart contact lenses, curved focal plane arrays and also curved electrical small antenna have been integrated into both graduate and undergraduate level classes. The students enrolled in the classes got excited about the topic and the unique experience of transformative research happening in the laboratory. The high school students who attended the workshop showed increased interest and tendency to pursue STEM degrees and careers in the future. The research findings on the development of conformal additive stamp printing and the yielded curvy devices, including the curvy imagers have been reported by many news outlets and have well received by the research community and the public.


Last Modified: 01/09/2023
Modified by: Cunjiang Yu
